content.raw: We use doxygen for documentation. Could you document all classes, functions and member variables. [Here](#!/osrf/vmrc/src/c4f07fead1416bfdb38d3cf643b8825f47780317/robotx_gazebo/include/robotx_gazebo/light_buoy_controller.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default)’s an example. One important part to document in the class section is the description and goal of the plugin and describe the SDF parameter that accepts.
content.html: We use doxygen for documentation. Could you document all classes, functions and member variables. Here’s an example. One important part to document in the class section is the description and goal of the plugin and describe the SDF parameter that accepts.

content.raw: You can add `#include <cmath>`, and then, use `M_PI`.
content.html: You can add #include <cmath>, and then, use M_PI.

content.raw: Use `<>` for consistency.
content.html: Use <> for consistency.

content.raw: Could you alphabetize these `#include`?
content.html: Could you alphabetize these #include?

content.raw: Nit: Could you add a space after all `//` comments?
content.html: Nit: Could you add a space after all // comments?

content.raw: Nit: Could you remove all extra breaklines? One empty line is OK.
content.html: Nit: Could you remove all extra breaklines? One empty line is OK.
2018?

content.raw: Nit: Avoid inline comments. Could you move it above?
content.html: Nit: Avoid inline comments. Could you move it above?

content.raw: Style: Could you make sure that there are no more than 80 characters per line?
content.html: Style: Could you make sure that there are no more than 80 characters per line?

content.raw: Nit: Add spaces between `=`.
content.html: Nit: Add spaces between =.

content.raw: I suggest to initialize `this->position` to origin and remove the `else` part. The same comment applies to other similar member variables.
content.html: I suggest to initialize this->position to origin and remove the else part. The same comment applies to other similar member variables.

content.raw: Can you use `std::unique_ptr` instead? This way we can forget about the `delete` part. You can use `reset` in the construction phase.
content.html: Can you use std::unique_ptr instead? This way we can forget about the delete part. You can use reset in the construction phase.

content.raw: **Initialise**
content.html: Initialise

content.raw: Can we use `std::bind` instead? No need to use `boost` for this anymore.
content.html: Can we use std::bind instead? No need to use boost for this anymore.

content.raw: Could you use `camelCase` names for all member variables? We’re following the Gazebo style here for consistency. Check other member variables too.
content.html: Could you use camelCase names for all member variables? We’re following the Gazebo style here for consistency. Check other member variables too.

content.raw: **coordinates**
content.html: coordinates

content.raw: I wonder if you could avoid doing these calculations “by hand” using the operators and functions in the math::Pose, math::Vector and math::Quaternion classes. For example, this is calculating the distance between two 3D points, and we should have a function for it. Then, we can add our custom noise model if we want.
content.html: I wonder if you could avoid doing these calculations “by hand” using the operators and functions in the math::Pose, math::Vector and math::Quaternion classes. For example, this is calculating the distance between two 3D points, and we should have a function for it. Then, we can add our custom noise model if we want.

We need a mutex and a lock here to protect this->position, as this callback might be executed asynchronously while accessing this->position in UpdateChild(). E.g.:

std::lock_guard<std::mutex> lock(this->mutex);

You'll need to add a similar lock in the block where this->mutex is used in UpdateChild().

content.raw: Just wondering if there’s an official pinger model. If there’s no mesh available, our 3D artist could create one and it’ll look nicer.
content.html: Just wondering if there’s an official pinger model. If there’s no mesh available, our 3D artist could create one and it’ll look nicer.

content.raw: Feel free to remove all sections that are commented.
content.html: Feel free to remove all sections that are commented.

content.raw: I'm not entirely sure how the pinger works but you only get one angle? So, the `Z` coordinate of the pinger doesn't affect the bearing?
content.html: I'm not entirely sure how the pinger works but you only get one angle? So, the Z coordinate of the pinger doesn't affect the bearing?

content.raw: Do we want to create two separate ROS packages just for the pinger? Maybe we could integrate the plugin into the existing usv\_gazebo\_plugins.
content.html: Do we want to create two separate ROS packages just for the pinger? Maybe we could integrate the plugin into the existing usv_gazebo_plugins.

content.raw:
I think it makes sense.  As stated, I am quite happy to restructure this as part of usv\_gazebo\_plugins.

I wrote a couple of python scripts, one shown here to move the pinger position, and another on my fork that visualises the position the pinger message.  Should they be part of wamv\_gazebo?

Regards,

Jonathan.
content.html:
I think it makes sense. As stated, I am quite happy to restructure this as part of usv_gazebo_plugins.

I wrote a couple of python scripts, one shown here to move the pinger position, and another on my fork that visualises the position the pinger message. Should they be part of wamv_gazebo?

Regards,

Jonathan.

content.raw: Could you add a new entry to the `Changelog.md` file?
content.html: Could you add a new entry to the Changelog.md file?

content.raw:
I think you need to add the dependency on the message generation. Something like:

    add_dependencies(gazebo_pinger_plugin
      pinger_msgs_generate_messages_cpp
    )
content.html:
I think you need to add the dependency on the message generation. Something like:

add_dependencies(gazebo_pinger_plugin
  pinger_msgs_generate_messages_cpp
)

content.raw: The message\_generation dependency is only required in a package that creates the message files.  Catkin should satisfy all dependencies automatically if messages are included as dependencies in a package.
content.html: The message_generation dependency is only required in a package that creates the message files. Catkin should satisfy all dependencies automatically if messages are included as dependencies in a package.

content.raw: Oh true, the message is coming from a separate package. Never mind.
content.html: Oh true, the message is coming from a separate package. Never mind.

content.raw: It would be nice if these positions can be read from a configuration file or the command line.
content.html: It would be nice if these positions can be read from a configuration file or the command line.

@JonathanWheare I had thought that you where going to build upon the acoustic-pinger branch where I had prototyped a solution: #!/osrf/vmrc/src/acoustic-pinger/

I haven’t had time to dig into your implementation yet, but was there a functional reason to start over? I am not married to the original example, but would help me efficiently review the PR to know the high-level design differences.

Sorry for any confusion.

content.raw:
My apologies Brian, I believe the misunderstanding is on my part.  

Carlos has provided a large amount of feedback on this pull request, and I have been considering how this could be improved.  I would suggest rejecting this pull request, and I will develop a new implementation based on the acoustic-pinger branch. 

Regards,

Jonathan.
content.html:
My apologies Brian, I believe the misunderstanding is on my part.

Carlos has provided a large amount of feedback on this pull request, and I have been considering how this could be improved. I would suggest rejecting this pull request, and I will develop a new implementation based on the acoustic-pinger branch.

Regards,

Jonathan.

content.raw:
No worries.  Again, I’m not pushing for the acoustic-pinger implementation, but wanted to understand the difference \(and haven’t had the time to dig into it yet\).  Perhaps you could take a look at the two and figure out an efficient path forward to take the best parts from each?

One thing we did discuss was improving the ROS message used for publishing the sensor values.  I used a `std_msgs::Float32MultiArray` populated with range, bearing, elevation in that order.  We think it would be better to create a custom message time \(as you did \) that includes a `std_msgs::header` [http://docs.ros.org/api/std\_msgs/html/msg/Header.html](http://docs.ros.org/api/std_msgs/html/msg/Header.html) to be consistent with the sensor\_msgs format.

Let me know how I can help.  I hope to get some time to dedicate to this next week.
content.html:
No worries. Again, I’m not pushing for the acoustic-pinger implementation, but wanted to understand the difference (and haven’t had the time to dig into it yet). Perhaps you could take a look at the two and figure out an efficient path forward to take the best parts from each?

One thing we did discuss was improving the ROS message used for publishing the sensor values. I used a std_msgs::Float32MultiArray populated with range, bearing, elevation in that order. We think it would be better to create a custom message time (as you did ) that includes a std_msgs::header http://docs.ros.org/api/std_msgs/html/msg/Header.html to be consistent with the sensor_msgs format.

Let me know how I can help. I hope to get some time to dedicate to this next week.

content.raw: @JonathanWheare , what's the status of this pull request? Are you working on the feedback/suggestions on this pull request directly or do you prefer to decline and create a new implementation based on the `acousting-pinger` branch?
content.html: @JonathanWheare , what's the status of this pull request? Are you working on the feedback/suggestions on this pull request directly or do you prefer to decline and create a new implementation based on the acousting-pinger branch?
